name: Notorious Movies and Actors Quiz | Classic Movies | 10 Questions

questions.text: "Cleopatra" (The Elizabeth Taylor version) is best remembered for the Taylor-Burton-Fisher triangle. It also caused incredible financial problems for the studio that produced it. What studio was it?
questions.explanation:
Twentieth Century Fox.

	A truly mediocre movie that gave new meaning to the words "over budget".

questions.text: Marilyn Monroe, another great star of that same time period, was fired from her last film and died a short time afterwards. Who was the director of the ill-fated "Something's Gotta Give"?
questions.explanation:
George Cukor.

	Poor Marilyn. The movie co-starred Dean Martin (and was later made with James Garner and Doris Day). Cimino was the director of "Heaven's Gate" (see  following question).

questions.text: "Heaven's Gate" was another movie that financially devastated a studio. Who was the star of the movie?
questions.explanation:
Kris Kristofferson.

	Michael Cimino direced. A long, dull, confusing movie. Gives new meaning to the word "fiasco".

questions.text: Claudine Longet was an actress and singer who may be best remembered for her private life. What happened?
options: Her boyfriend died due to an  accidental overdose
questions.explanation:
She shot her boyfriend.

	The gun went off. Was it an accident?

questions.text: Sarah Miles starred with Burt Reynolds in the western, "The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing". She ended up on trial for murder. Who was the victim?
questions.explanation:
Her business manager.

	Found dead in her room. Accident, suicide or murder?

questions.text: "The Misfits" is remembered as the last movie ever completed by which of the following?
options: Marilyn Monroe, Clark Gable, Montgomery Clift
questions.explanation:
Marilyn Monroe, Clark Gable.

	An Arthur Miller script for his wife. A bad movie, a disintegrating marriage (Miller and Monroe), and a rough, rugged climate. Did the delays caused by Marilyn's problems affect Gable's health? He died shortly after completion of the movie. Monroe attempted another movie (see question 2), but was fired from the picture before its completion.

questions.text: Errol Flynn is as famous for his lifestyle as for his movies. His son, Sean Flynn, made a few Flynn-like movies before disappearing in Vietnam. Which movie was one of his?
questions.explanation:
Son of Captain Blood.

	He emulated his father in a "Captain Blood" type movie. Apparently, a short life.

questions.text: Speaking of Errol Flynn, he co-starred (late in his career) in the movie "Too Much, Too Soon". This was the sad-but-true story of a member of another famous movie family. Which one?
questions.explanation:
Barrymore.

	Diana Barrymore was the daughter of John Barrymore. The movie was based on her autobiography. Tough life.

questions.text: Vic Morrow was tragically killed while filming "Twilight Zone, the Movie". Director John Landis was charged with criminal negligence. What happened to him?
options: He was able to plea bargain
He was never brought  to trial
questions.explanation:
He was acquitted.

	He was tried and acquitted.

questions.text: This movie is best remembered due to the suspicions that the filming in the American West may have contributed to the subsequent cancer deaths of John Wayne, Susan Hayward and Dick Powell.
questions.explanation:
The Conqueror.

	Filmed in the vicinity of previous nuclear testing. (Of course, Wayne was a heavy smoker - and cancer is not exactly uncommon. Still...?)Wayne was in "Blood Alley" and "Undefeated". Hayward starred in "Soldier of Fortune" (with Clark Gable).
